Description: Gilded glass bottle; clear yellowish decorated with gold applied in suspension and then fired. The lower frieze shows an eagle with outstretched wings between pomegranate trees; the narrower band around the centre carries a cursive Arabic inscription, naming the ruler Imad al-Din Zengi. A broad band above the shoulder depicts a female dancer beside a pomegranate tree, holding a castanet in her left hand, and another female playing a harp. The vessel has a pronounced kick but the neck has broken off at the bottom; fragment.
Curator's comments: Inscribed with the name of Imad al-Din Zengi who ruled Mosul as Atabeg (regent) for the Seljuqs of Anatolia. The object was acquired in Turkey although it has been attributed a Syrian place of production on stylistic grounds, possibly in error. After the vessel was first acquired, the inscription was read by A.G. Ellis as "Sultan of Sultans Imad al-Din" and therefore (mis) attributed to one of the Mamluk Sultans of Egypt, al-Malik al-Salih Imad al-Din Ismail who ruled from 1342-1345, and thus a different and later individual to that referred to. The decoration is executed in particles of gold suspended in liquid. The gold is painted onto the glass which was then reheated to form the decoration.
